P1.Explanation: White places a pawn in the center on d4, controlling e5 and c5 squares and aiming for central control.

P2.Explanation: Black mirrors White's pawn move, challenging the center directly.

P3.Explanation: White offers a pawn to gain further central control and open lines for the pieces.

P4.Explanation: This is the hallmark of the Albin Countergambit. Black sacrifices the e-pawn to destabilize White's center and create counterplay.

P5.Explanation: White accepts the pawn sacrifice, opening up the center and leaving Black with opportunities to counterattack.

P6.Explanation: Black pushes the d-pawn forward, creating a strong, advanced pawn that can disrupt White's position.

P7.Explanation: White develops the knight to attack the advanced pawn and prepares to continue development.

P8.Explanation: Black brings the knight into the game, adding pressure to the pawn on e5 and supporting the advanced d-pawn.

P9.T9: Step 9: White plays 5. a3 to control b4
P9.Explanation: White prevents Black from developing the bishop to b4 and prepares to solidify their position.

P10.Explanation: Black develops the bishop to an active square, pinning the knight on f3 and increasing pressure on White's position.
